awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Broadening Participation and Building Pathways in Computer Science (CS) through Concurrent Enrollment
awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies the implementation and outcomes of Concurrent Enrollment (CE) programs as a vehicle for broadening participation in high school to college pathways in Computer Science (CS). The Mobile Computer Science Principles (Mobile CSP) project at the College of St. Scholastica, an established curriculum endorsed by the College Board for its alignment with the Advanced Placement (AP) CSP framework, has formed a Research-Practitioner Partnership (RPP) with CE programs at Capital Community College in Hartford, Connecticut and Southwest Minnesota State University in Minnesota and with partner school districts in each state.

The RPP project explores whether CS through CE can broaden the high school to college pathway in computing disciplines for those traditionally underrepresented in these fields--female, underrepresented minority, and low-SES students. While the AP CSP course has enrolled a more diverse group of students than previous AP CS courses, it is not as diverse as other AP courses. CE programs appear to have better penetration than AP among schools that predominantly serve underrepresented minorities and low-SES students, showing promise for broadening participation in other disciplines and encouraging college matriculation.

By implementing and studying CS through CE in two different contexts (rural and low-SES in Minnesota and urban, diverse, and low-SES in Connecticut), the project contributes to transforming the educational pathways in CS in a variety of contexts and to understanding the supports and barriers to implementing CSP as CE with a broadening-participation goal. This project provides professional development and support of 40 high school teachers to teach a CE version of the Mobile CSP course among partnering school districts over the course of 3 years. The goals of this RPP project are (1) to examine and address the supports and barriers to implementing and sustaining Mobile CSP as a concurrent enrollment course and (2) to study whether a CE implementation of the CSP course broadens participation in computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
The project included the following three objectives and two research questions. The status of each at the end of the project is provided below.


OBJECTIVES

  1. CSP is offered in 40 high schools to up to 700 students, for college credit through concurrent enrollment programs in urban Connecticut and rural Minnesota.
    Mobile CSP was offered in concurrent enrollment format in at least 30 schools (goal: 40) with 38 teachers trained (goal: 40) and 742 students completing the course (goal: 700). Mobile CSP was offered as a concurrent enrollment course through Southwest Minnesota State University and Capital Community College in Connecticut.
  2. CSP-CE is taught in high schools by qualified teachers using inclusive teaching practices.
    The Mobile CSP professional development and curriculum was updated to enhance inclusive teaching practices throughout the project. All teachers were considered qualified by the higher education institution as qualified to teach the course as concurrent enrollment. Qualified in this instance means that the teacher both completed Mobile CSP-CE professional development and met the requirements to be faculty by the concurrent enrollment program.
  3. CSP-CE classrooms more closely reflect the demographics of their schools than other CS courses.
    1. While this did not change in initial years, the longer a teacher taught, the more closely their class reflected school demographics.
    2. While not initially a focus, we examined the student outcomes in terms of passing the course and found that students pass the course at higher rates than pass the AP CSP exam
  2021-22 2022-23
  # of Students % of Students # of Students % of Students
Total Enrollment 161 100.00% 157 100%
Male 111 68.94% 102 64.97%
Female 48 29.81% 55 35.03%
White 97 60.25% 80 50.95%
Asian 22 13.66% 9 5.73%
Black or African-American 14 8.70% 14 8.92%
Hispanic n/a n/a 20 12.73%
American Indian or Alaskan Native 0 0.00% 3 1.91%
Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander 0 0.00% 0 0%
Two or more races 6 3.73% 16 10.19%
Choose not to respond/Unknown 21 13.04% 15 9.55%

 


RESEARCH QUESTIONS

RQA - What are the supports and barriers to implementing and sustaining the Computer Science Principles (Mobile CSP) as a concurrent enrollment course?

Supports for CSP as a CE course included the equity focus of the CS departments in each college with CE programs, the funding models for CE in each state so that the burden for payment of the course credit was not placed on the student or their family, and the existing Mobile CSP curriculum and professional development to support new-to-CS teachers. 

Barriers for CSP as a CE course included some logistics for students to enroll in the CE program initially, state policies around who could and could not take CS (e.g., meeting GPA requirements or class standing requirements), and each state's CS policy context (Minnesota had low awareness of the need for CS courses while many Connecticut schools were already offering CSP as an AP course).

RQB - Does a Concurrent Enrollment (CE) implementation of Computer Science Principles broaden participation in computing?

Schools that had existing systems to offer CE, but not Advanced Placement (AP) courses, were able to add Mobile CSP-CE and students who did not have access to CS previously now had access. Types of schools that, in general, offer CE instead of AP for advanced coursework, include rural and technical schools.


Last Modified: 01/28/2025
Modified by: Jennifer L Rosato

The project included the following three objectives and two research questions. The status of each at the end of the project is provided below.



OBJECTIVES

CSP is offered in 40 high schools to up to 700 students, for college credit through concurrent enrollment programs in urban Connecticut and rural Minnesota.
Mobile CSP was offered in concurrent enrollment format in at least 30 schools (goal: 40) with 38 teachers trained (goal: 40) and 742 students completing the course (goal: 700). Mobile CSP was offered as a concurrent enrollment course through Southwest Minnesota State University and Capital Community College in Connecticut.
CSP-CE is taught in high schools by qualified teachers using inclusive teaching practices.
The Mobile CSP professional development and curriculum was updated to enhance inclusive teaching practices throughout the project. All teachers were considered qualified by the higher education institution as qualified to teach the course as concurrent enrollment. Qualified in this instance means that the teacher both completed Mobile CSP-CE professional development and met the requirements to be faculty by the concurrent enrollment program.
CSP-CE classrooms more closely reflect the demographics of their schools than other CS courses.
While this did not change in initial years, the longer a teacher taught, the more closely their class reflected school demographics.
While not initially a focus, we examined the student outcomes in terms of passing the course and found that students pass the course at higher rates than pass the AP CSP exam
